Hopkins'QuestFor Culture;
Linkletter ToSpeak in April
By STEPHEN SHRIVER
Art Linkletter. the renowned
radio and television personality,
Will speak here on April 4th as
part of his continuing "dialogue"
with American college students.
Linkletter will appear at Shriver
Hall at 4 p.m. under the sponsorship of the Hopkins Student As-,

sociation.
The topic of his talk, to be
followed by a question-and-answer session, will be "The Entertainer And Politics." It will be
open to all students and the public without admission.
Linkletter Tour
Linkletter is touring the na-

Sex Talk To Come
Dr. Graham B. BlaMe, Chief
of Psychiatry, Health Service,
Harvard University, will speak
on "Stress and Distress in College" this afternoon in Levering
Hall at 4 p.m. The lecture is
sponsored by the Student Association.
Dr. Blaine will stress sex behavior, identity formation, and
independence vs. dependence in
his address. He will have an informal dinner discussion afterwards with members of the administration, faculty, and clergy
concerning the responsibility of
the University and the Church
to the college student.
Expert in Student Behavior
The psychiatrist, an expert in

the field of student behavior, has
recently published articles on
"College Students and Moral
Values", "Motivation and Attitudes of Youth", and "Emotional
Problems of the Students."
Blaine took his M.D. from Columbia College of Psychiatrists
and Surgeons in 1943 after attending Harvard as an undergraduate. He is a member of the
New York Academy of Medicine.
Chairman of the Professional
Policy Board, the Academy of
Religion and Mental Health, a
member of the American Psychiatry Association and the
Mental Hygiene Committee of
the American College Health Association.

tion's colleges wider the auspices
of the Royal Crown (Cola) University Series. The series is described as "Art Linkletter and
the American Student: A Dialogue."
The "free-wheeling" questionand-answer sessions provide the
gist for the "dialogue." Mr. Linkletter finds these both challenging and heartening.
The 1962 "Grandfather of the
Year" (he is responsible for five)
is an expert speaker. For twenty
years he has regularly moved millions through such formidable
programs as "People Are Funny"
and "Art Linkletter's House
Party."
He is also a political activist. A
staunch defender of the actor's
right to turn politician, he
stresses the importance of television in "making" a politician.
Unafraid to express his political
opinions, Mr. Linkletter is also
well suited to follow his tubeteasers, Lightfoot Murphy and
Tough Ronnie. into the political
House Party.

Sheep's Time To Awaken
By GERALD BRECHER
Professor John Roche, President Johnson's Egghead-in-residence at the White House, once
remarked that we would have
no real opposition to the war in
Viet Nam if we'd only stop drafting sons of the upper-middle
class. This is a remark that
makes a great deal more sense
than it would seem, once we
realize that virtually all the
adult opposition to the war
comes from the afore-mentioned
social class, and that of the
younger people from their children. Prof. Roche is merely suggesting, and correctly, I would
submit, tha•t one of the greatest
components of the dissent over
the war is the fear of the draft
by a group of people who have
the most to fear from it.
It's really quite simple. Without the war in Viet Nam, the
draft is really not a factor in
too many people's lives. With the
war being maintained at its present level, however, no one is
really immune from draft pressures. Now with the poorer segments of the population, the
Army has always been a healthful and welcome respite from the
drudgery of a marginal existence. It's for damn sure that the
average Black from South Baltimore isn't about to get the opportunity to travel to places like
Okinawa or Seoul, or Stuttgart
without the kind services of the
G.I. travel agency.

We admit that the pay is not
all that great. But, then again,
the bulk of the draftees weren't
doing all that better on the outside anyway; and besides, the
fringe benefits, as we have
pointed out, are well worth the
cut in cash pay.
This is all very nice: very nice
that is, if your future isn't about
to be too very exciting—you
know, sort of the same shoddy
life your folks have been living for generations. Very nice—
if your ambitions don't run any
further than a 'good' job at a
hundred and a half a week, a
cheap house in a lousy suburb,
and the same for your kids, and
hopefully theirs as well.The Army
can't hurt you then; except
maybe you might get killed. But
that's the risk you run, and
you'll be defending our country—
all that jazz. It'll be a good experience.

The most significant problem of the draft which
faces Congress now is what to do with undergraduates.
Everyone seems to agree that the best soldier—which we
and
take to mean he who can be most easily molded
who values his life the highest—is the 19 year old. This
we agree with, not for the above reasons, but rather because it would cause the least interruption of his life.
Hopefully, after his two year service he would be ind him through the
clined to use the scholarship afforde'
G.L Bill to further his education.
But there are many 18 and 19 year olds—presumably the bulk of Hopkins students are or were in
this category—who plan to earn Ph.D.'s, a goal which
demands 8 to 10 years of their lives. They are the one
percent of our population, the mentally privileged. They
can not afford an added two years of what would be
wasted time.
If this one percent elite should in fact be deferred
from the draft, the only feasible way to achieve it is
through a challenging and demanding set of exams.
This does not mean the infamous and fatuous "war
boards" of the last two years, but rather something in
the line of comprehensive exams in a person's major
area of stiffly, whether it be medicine, dentistry, or
English.
This is an "elitist" view, but applicable only for
those capable of earning a Ph.D. degree. Educational
deferments are now held by 1.7 million students. Under
the suggested system above, only about 200,000 deferments would be awarded. Everyone else would be included in the pool of eligible men at 19, and would have
to serve if chosen. Only after their two years were
finished would they be able to pursue the luxury of a
college education.

without his draft board sending

of having the dough to begin

Our beloved President makes
a big deal of making the draft
FAIR. But let's just realize who
the draft is really unfair to. It's
not the slum kid who's getting
the raw deal out of the Army.
Hell, the Army can't be any
worse than where he came from
in the first place. But for the Big
Noise from Winetka or Shaker
Heights or Grosse Pointe or
Great Neck, the draft is a royal
shaft. The Army is very simply,
a drag. You don't get anything
out of it. You don't really do
anyone any good by being in it,
and conceivably, you could really
get screwed up by the whole
thing. Who needs it, really?

Is talking. You see, these kids

their share of dormitory living—
or at least they've gone to sleep

have lots of nice clothes; and
if they need to look military.
they can bop down to Limbo, or
up to the attic and cull from
Daddy's old officer's uniforms.
(What is this enlist man jazz,
anyhow?)

The Army is, if you come from

Fast-talking your parents
is the hard way
to get to Britain.
Fact-talk instead.
Tell them exactly what your trip will cost. Our free booklets help you calculate it.
One lists prices of organized student tours. They start
around $650. If you want to travel on your own and take
potluck on meeting people —which may be the most fun
of all—add things up for yourself.
Start with a charter flight if your school has one. Or see
our booklet on group flights, student ships, and the bargain airline.
Add low costs for getting around Britain. Our booklets
tell you about 3¢-per-mile buses and the rail-and-boat
pass that takes you up to 1,000 miles for $30. Consider
hiking too. Wordsworth did.
Multiply the number of your nights in Britain by cost
of bed and breakfast or a room in a college residence hall.
If you're hiking or biking, count on about 70¢ for youth
hostels. At this rate you may be able to stay all summer.
Allow about $1 a meal in London, less in the country.
The booklets say which restaurants and pubs are popular

with convivial British students.
And the booklets mention the fantastically low cost of
concerts and plays in Britain. You can sit in "the gods-galleries up near Heaven—for 75.A lot of outdoor entertainment, like concerts and folk-singing, is free.
Clip the coupon. Add everything up. And tell your
parents you can spend this summer in Britain for about
what it costs to hang around the house.

design, construction, production, marketing, research

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 17, 1967

NEWS -LETTER

Sheep's Time To Awaken
By GERALD BRECHER
Professor John Roche, President Johnson's Egghead-in-residence at the White House, once
remarked that we would have
no real opposition to the war in
Viet Nam if we'd only stop drafting sons of the upper-middle
class. This is a remark that
makes a great deal more sense
than it would seem, once we
realize that virtually all the
adult opposition to the war
comes from the afore-mentioned
social class, and that of the
younger people from their children. Prof. Roche is merely suggesting, and correctly, I would
submit, tha•t one of the greatest
components of the dissent over
the war is the fear of the draft
by a group of people who have
the most to fear from it.
It's really quite simple. Without the war in Viet Nam, the
draft is really not a factor in
too many people's lives. With the
war being maintained at its present level, however, no one is
really immune from draft pressures. Now with the poorer segments of the population, the
Army has always been a healthful and welcome respite from the
drudgery of a marginal existence. It's for damn sure that the
average Black from South Baltimore isn't about to get the opportunity to travel to places like
Okinawa or Seoul, or Stuttgart
without the kind services of the
G.I. travel agency.

We admit that the pay is not
all that great. But, then again,
the bulk of the draftees weren't
doing all that better on the outside anyway; and besides, the
fringe benefits, as we have
pointed out, are well worth the
cut in cash pay.
This is all very nice: very nice
that is, if your future isn't about
to be too very exciting—you
know, sort of the same shoddy
life your folks have been living for generations. Very nice—
if your ambitions don't run any
further than a 'good' job at a
hundred and a half a week, a
cheap house in a lousy suburb,
and the same for your kids, and
hopefully theirs as well.The Army
can't hurt you then; except
maybe you might get killed. But
that's the risk you run, and
you'll be defending our country—
all that jazz. It'll be a good experience.

The most significant problem of the draft which

Everyone seems to agree that the best soldier—which we
and
take to mean he who can be most easily molded
who values his life the highest—is the 19 year old. This

Hopefully, after his two year service he would be ind him through the

But there are many 18 and 19 year olds—presumably the bulk of Hopkins students are or were in
this category—who plan to earn Ph.D.'s, a goal which
demands 8 to 10 years of their lives. They are the one
percent of our population, the mentally privileged. They
can not afford an added two years of what would be
wasted time.
If this one percent elite should in fact be deferred
from the draft, the only feasible way to achieve it is
through a challenging and demanding set of exams.
This does not mean the infamous and fatuous "war
boards" of the last two years, but rather something in
the line of comprehensive exams in a person's major
area of stiffly, whether it be medicine, dentistry, or
English.
This is an "elitist" view, but applicable only for
those capable of earning a Ph.D. degree. Educational
deferments are now held by 1.7 million students. Under
the suggested system above, only about 200,000 deferments would be awarded. Everyone else would be included in the pool of eligible men at 19, and would have
to serve if chosen. Only after their two years were
finished would they be able to pursue the luxury of a
college education.

of having the dough to begin

Our beloved President makes
a big deal of making the draft
FAIR. But let's just realize who
the draft is really unfair to. It's

the raw deal out of the Army.
Hell, the Army can't be any
worse than where he came from
in the first place. But for the Big
Noise from Winetka or Shaker
Heights or Grosse Pointe or
Great Neck, the draft is a royal
shaft. The Army is very simply,
a drag. You don't get anything
out of it. You don't really do
anyone any good by being in it,
and conceivably, you could really
get screwed up by the whole
thing. Who needs it, really?

they can bop down to Limbo, or

Fast-talking your parents
is the hard way
to get to Britain.
Fact-talk instead.
Tell them exactly what your trip will cost. Our free booklets help you calculate it.
One lists prices of organized student tours. They start
around $650. If you want to travel on your own and take
potluck on meeting people —which may be the most fun
of all—add things up for yourself.
Start with a charter flight if your school has one. Or see
our booklet on group flights, student ships, and the bargain airline.
Add low costs for getting around Britain. Our booklets
tell you about 3¢-per-mile buses and the rail-and-boat
pass that takes you up to 1,000 miles for $30. Consider
hiking too. Wordsworth did.
Multiply the number of your nights in Britain by cost
of bed and breakfast or a room in a college residence hall.
If you're hiking or biking, count on about 70¢ for youth
hostels. At this rate you may be able to stay all summer.
Allow about $1 a meal in London, less in the country.
The booklets say which restaurants and pubs are popular

with convivial British students.
And the booklets mention the fantastically low cost of
concerts and plays in Britain. You can sit in "the gods-galleries up near Heaven—for 75.A lot of outdoor entertainment, like concerts and folk-singing, is free.
Clip the coupon. Add everything up. And tell your
parents you can spend this summer in Britain for about
what it costs to hang around the house.

Coach Sotir plans to run some
of the attackmen at mid-field so
as not to waste their abilities.
Doug Honig, the All-Long Island
Team star from Manhassett, is
sure to lead this unit. Honig was
the top scorer on Long Island
last year with 92 points, with
twenty-two goals and 70 assists
to his credit.
Other attackmen demonstrating potential include Stu Kahl,
1st Team All-Maryland, Russ
Moore, All-League star from
Mineola, New York, and Dave
Roberts, another top Maryland

prospect.
The midfield contingent should
count heavily on Jim Lotto, who
scored thirty-three goals for
Uniondale, New York last year
and Andy Fisher. Other top prospects include footballer Paul
Weiss, who never played lacrosse
before, Dan Rosenfeld and Stu
Fogel.
